qas.question: What is the county flower of Lancaster?
Where can the red rose of lancaster be found?

answers.text: on the county's heraldic badge and flag

qas.question: What is on the traditional Lancashire flag?

answers.text: a red rose on a white field

qas.question: What is on the official Lancashire flag?

answers.text: red rose on a gold field

qas.question: Whos flag officially is a red rose on a white field?
In what century was the traditional Lancashire Flag established?
In what century was the Flag Institute founded?
In what century did Montrose register the Lancaster Flag?

plausible_answers.text: red rose on a gold field

context: <a0_0>The Red Rose of Lancaster<a0_0/> is the county flower found <a1_0>on the county's heraldic badge and flag<a1_0/>. The rose was a symbol of the House of Lancaster, immortalised in the verse "In the battle for England's head/York was white, Lancaster red" (referring to the <b5_0><b6_0><b7_0>15th-century<b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/> Wars of the Roses). The traditional Lancashire flag, <a2_0>a red rose on a white field<a2_0/>, was not officially registered. When an attempt was made to register it with the Flag Institute it was found that it was officially registered by <a4_0>Montrose in Scotland<a4_0/>, several hundred years earlier with the Lyon Office. Lancashire's official flag is registered as a <a3_0><b8_0>red rose on a gold field<b8_0/><a3_0/>.
